results.title: Pot-Bouille = House of Lovers
results.creator_credit: Julien Duvivier, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
Penniless Octave Mouret arrives in Paris at the turn of the Century to take up a job as assistant in a draper shop run by Madame Hedouin. She takes a fancy to him, as do two girls in the house where he lodges. In this adaptation of Zola’s novel Duvivier is less interested in Octave than in the life of the building, a real melting pot of the vices of the 19th century Paris bourgeoisie.

Credits: Producers, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Henri Jeanson, Leo Joannon, Julien Duvivier ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Jean Wiener ; art direction, Leon Barsacq.
Cast: Gerard Philippe, Danielle Darrieux, Dany Carrel, Anouk Aimee, Jacques Rispal, Jane Marken, Olivier Hussenot.

results.title: Eadweard Muybridge: zoopraxographer
results.creator_credit: Thom Andersen and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Documents the pioneering photographic work of Eadweard Muybridge (1830-1904) in which he rigorously analysed human and animal motion. Muybridge’s multiple camera techniques and his projection device, the zoopraxiscope, were technical curiosities unnecessary for the development of the modern motion picture but through them he overcame a philosophical obstacle. He demonstrated empirically that the infinite flux of time could be reconstructed from a finite number of photographs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Thom Andersen and University of California, Los Angeles

results.title: L'armee des Ombres = the Shadow Army
results.brief_description:
Melville adopted the thriller format for his account of the Resistance. It can be regarded as the third instalment of a trilogy about life in France under German occupation started with ‘Le silence de la mer’ (1949) and ‘Leon Morin, pretre’ (1961), both held in our collection. Far from the usual romantic cliches showing handsome young men playing tricks with the Nazis and falling in love with sublime women, the substance of the movie is reality. It depicts a ‘shadow army’ made of courageous men who are ready to sacrifice their lives but are aware of the huge cost they will eventually have to pay. It shows the cruel and sometimes inhuman choices they have to make in order to survive. Both writer Joseph Kessel and co-writer and director Jean-Pierre Melville belonged to this ‘Army in the shadows’. Andre Dewavrin (known as Colonel Passy in the Resistance) plays himself.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Dorfmann ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writer, Jean-Pierre Melville ; photography, Pierre Lhomme, Walter Wottitz ; music, Eric Demarsan.
Cast: Lino Ventura, Simone Signoret, Paul Meurisse, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Nathalie Delon, Paul Crauchet, Claude Mann, Christian Barbier, Serge Reggiani, Alain Mottet, Andre Dewavrin.

results.title: Pour la Peau D'un Flic = for a Cop's Hide
results.brief_description:
Choucas, a former cop turned private investigator, is asked by an old lady to investigate the disappearance of a young blind girl. It all seem a very mundane case. But shortly after starting the investigation, Choucas receives the visit of a very strange and nosy person. Then, later on, the old lady is murdered on her way to a meeting with Choucas.

Credits: Producer, director, Alain Delon ; writers, Alain Delon, Christopher Frank ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Oscar Benton ; art direction, Theo Meurisse.
Cast: Alain Delon, Anne Parillaud, Daniel Ceccaldi, Michel Auclair.

results.title: La Drolesse = the Hussy
results.creator_credit: Jacques Doillon, Daniele Delorme and Yves Robert
results.brief_description:
Twenty-year old misfit Francois kidnaps gawky Mado, an 11 year-old who is neglected by her family. Francois locks up Mado in his attic. Instead of feeling fear, Mado enters into the spirit of the abduction, and they joust with one another, increasingly finding love and comfort in their relationship. Doillon’s intimate, small-scale films are marked by recurrent themes of Oedipal and gender conflicts - especially between fathers and daughters - which, although not strictly autobiographical, often rework events from his life. Doillon’s mise-en-scene favours pared-down, claustrophobic settings and situations, contrasting with the violent emotions depicted. Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. “The comapnion to French cinema”. London: BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producers, Daniele Delorme, Yves Robert ; director, Jacques Doillon ; writer, Jacques Doillon ; photography, Philippe Rousselot ; art direction, Jean-Denis Robert.
Cast: Claude Hebert, Madeleine Desdevises.

results.title: Sale Reveur = Dirty Dreamer
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Perier, Daniele Delorme and Yves Robert
results.brief_description:
Jerome, is a stuntcar racer still living out teenage fantasies of being Paul Newman. Although surrounded by an urban jungle of parking lots and high rise towers, he likes to think of himself as ‘Hud’ and his long suffering girlfriend does nothing to play down the fantasy.

Credits: Producers, Yves Robert, Daniele Delorme ; director, Jean-Marie Perier ; writers, Jean-Marie Perier, Pascal Jardin, Lucien Elia ; photography, Yves Lafaye ; music, Sydney Bechet, Jacques Dutronc ; decors, Theo Meurisse.
Cast: Jacques dutronc, Lea Massari, Jean Bouise, Maurice Benichou, Nathalie Perier, Greg Germain, Anemone.

results.title: Djeli: Conte D'aujourd'hui = Bloodline: A Modern Tale
results.brief_description:
Fanta and Karamoko, two students from Ivory Coast, are in love and making plans to marry. They come from the same village and their families have known each other for a long time. However, Karamoko, is the son a a griot and he is not allowed to marry Fanta who descends from a noble lineage. The families oppose the union in the name of tradition.

Credits: Producer, director, Fadika Kramo-Lancine ; photography, Christian Lacoste, N’Gouan Kacou ; music, Kyate Sori Kandia.
Cast: Tatou Ouatara, Joachim Ouatara Yao

results.title: Le Diable Dans la Boite = the Devil in the Box
results.brief_description:
Satire about the expendability of personnel in a big contracting company challenged by the hunger strike of a young executive when he is fired with the vague reason of a re-structuring.

Credits: Producer, Mag Bodard ; director, Pierre Lary ; writers, Jean-Claude Carriere, Hugue Deboisieux, Pierre Lary ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Jean-Claude Dequeant.
Cast: Jean Rochefort, Michel Lonsdale, Dominique Labourier, Anouk Ferjac, Micheline Presle.

results.title: Le Mur = the Wall
results.brief_description:
Three prisoners await execution by firing squad after their capture during the Spanish Civil War. Pablo is a loyalist jailed after he searched for his brother. An Irish mercenary and a Belgian physician are his cellmates. Flashbacks recall their lives before the war as they spend their last moments waiting for their date with death.

Credits: Producer, Claude Jaeger ; director, Serge Roullet ; writers, Jean-Paul Sartre, Serge Roullet ; photography, Denys Clerval ; music, Edgardo Canton ; assistant director, Benoit Jacquot.
Cast: Michel del castillo, Denis Maharrey, Matthieu Klossowski, Bernard Anglade, Rene Darmon, Jorge Lavelli, Peter Kassovitz.

results.title: French Cancan
results.brief_description:
Beautifully photographed, this comedy-drama chronicles the revival of Paris’ most notorious dance as it tells the story of a theater producer who turns a humble washerwoman into a star at the Moulin Rouge. Renoir’s return to film-making in France after 15 years of absence is an exuberant and affectionate homage to the theatre of ‘La Belle Epoque’ (Edith Piaf and Patachou appear briefly as stars of the day.) It also gave him the opportunity to work with Gabin again, having made three films with him in the 1930s. According to Raymond Durgnat, Renoir’s can-can dancers “unleash the insolence not only of proletarian energy, but of the aggressive female, and storm the 19th century bourgeois male patriarchy… A river of feminine energy flows devastatingly, but not destructively, through society”.

Credits: Producer, Louis Wipf ; director, Jean Renoir ; writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Van Parys ; art direction, Max Douy ; costumes, Rosine Delamare ; assistant director, Pierre Kast.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Francoise Arnoul, Maria Felix, Jean-Roger Caussimon, Gianni Esposito.
